ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend American Scholars. I think it accomplished is purpose of providing a space for the cohort to engage in a wide array of discussions (that I'm sure will be ongoing) within the field.
It is a great class for cohort bonding and really works in developing and locating your community at Yale.

American Scholars is a necessary step towards getting through your first semester as a graduate student. Despite it not always being a fulfilling experience, you get to spend time with your cohort, which seems to get more rare as the semesters continue. Generally, I would recommend the class, though it might be frustrating to not have the option to take another class that may indeed be better fit.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I don't know that the course contributed to my specific dissertation/research in a direct way, but it certainly gave me a sense of the kinds of questions that are being asked and a broader understanding of (re)sources as I continue to develop my research.
I have a better sense of which faculty members I might want to collaborate with in the coming years.

It is a schematic class that aims to get students acquainted with life, work, and study at Yale. By allowing us to sample a range of professors' interests and works it allows for students to engage with people's work who may they otherwise never come across. It is a really important course for one beginning their career at Yale.
I wish I could say my knowledge of American Studies was deepened. I do think that another class would have prepared me more substantially for my future dissertation/research.
